title: Norwegian Wood - Haruki Murakami
description:
Norwegian Wood (Ã£Æ’Å½Ã£Æ’Â«Ã£â€šÂ¦Ã£â€šÂ§Ã£â€šÂ¤Ã£ï¿½Â®Ã¦Â£Â® Noruwei no Mori?) is a 1987 novel by Japanese author Haruki Murakami.[1] The novel is a nostalgic story of loss and burgeoning sexuality.[2] It is told from the first-person perspective of Toru Watanabe, who looks back on his days as a college student living in Tokyo.[3] Through Watanabe's reminiscences we see him develop relationships with two very different women Ã¢â‚¬â€ the beautiful yet emotionally troubled Naoko, and the outgoing, lively Midori.[4]

The novel is set in Tokyo during the late 1960s, at a time when Japanese students, like those of many other nations, were protesting against the established order.[5] While it serves as the backdrop against which the events of the novel unfold, Murakami (through the eyes of Watanabe and Midori) portrays the student movement as largely weak-willed and hypocritical.
